facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 232 of 1964 is before the Civil Appellate Jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 232 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal is from the Judgment and order dated 23rd October 1960 of Madras High Court in Appeal No. 237 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated the 23rd October, 1960 of the Madras High Court in Appeal No. 237 of 1958.

facts.text: Appellant held the post of Deputy Tahsildar in the Revenue Department of the Government of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant held the post of Deputy Tahsildar in the Revenue Department of the Government of Madras.

facts.text: Disciplinary proceedings started against appellant on twelve charges of acceptance of illegal gratification during his office as Special Loans Deputy Tahsildar, Cuddalore, South Arcot District.

anchor.surface_text: Dis- ciplinary proceedings were started against him on twelve charges of acceptance of illegal gratification during his office as Special Loans Deputy Tahsildar, Cuddalore, South Ascot District.

facts.text: Disciplinary proceedings started against three subordinates on similar charges.

anchor.surface_text: Disciplinary proceedings were started against three of his subordinates also on similar charges.

facts.text: Appellant placed under suspension and relieved of duties on May 20, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On May, 20, 1949, he was placed under suspension and relieved of his duties.

facts.text: Disciplinary Proceedings Tribunal directed consolidation and common hearing of enquiries against appellant and other three civil servants.

anchor.surface_text: The Disciplinary Proceedings Tribunal directed the companysolidation and companymon hearing of the enquiries against the appellant and the other three civil servants.

facts.text: Appellant asked for permission to engage counsel at the enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant asked for permission to engage a companynsel at the enquiry.

facts.text: Tribunal refused permission by order dated May 31, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated May 31, 1949, the Tribunal refused to give the permission.

facts.text: Enquiry held on June 13, 14 and 15.

anchor.surface_text: The enquiry was held on June 13, 14 and 15.

facts.text: Other three civil servants represented by counsel Sri. Kalyanasundaram at the hearing.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing, the other three civil servants were represented by companynsel, Sri. Kalyanasundaram.

facts.text: On June 13, appellant prayed for adjournment.

anchor.surface_text: On June 13, the appellant prayed for an adjournment.

facts.text: Tribunal declined to grant adjournment and told appellant he could engage Sri. Kalyanasundaram.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal declined to grant the adjournment and told the appellant that he was at liberty to engage Sri. Kalyanasundaram as his companynsel.

facts.text: Appellant availed services of Sri. Kalyanasundaram and was represented by him throughout the enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon availed himself of the services of Sri. Kalyanasundaram, and was represented by him throughout the enquiry.

facts.text: Tribunal submitted report on June 30 stating charges proved and recommending dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: On June 30, the Tribunal submitted a report stating that the charges against the appellant were proved and recommending his dismissal.

facts.text: Government issued notice on September 16 asking to show cause why dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: On September 16, the Government issued a numberice to him asking him to show cause why he should number be dismissed from service.

facts.text: Appellant submitted written representation on November 12, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On November 12, 1949, he submitted his written representation.

facts.text: Government directed dismissal from service with effect from May 20, 1949 on October 17, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On October 17, 1950, the Government directed that he be dismissed from service with effect from May 20, 1949.

facts.text: Appellant instituted suit for declaration that dismissal order dated October 17, 1950 is illegal and void.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant instituted the suit asking for a declaration that the order dated October 17, 1950 dismissing him from service is illegal and void.

facts.text: Trial Court dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court dismissed the suit, and,

facts.text: High Court of Madras affirmed the decree on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: this decree was affirmed on appeal by the High Court of Madras.

facts.text: Appellant appeals to this Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant number appeals to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: In written representation dated November 12, 1949, appellant did not allege prejudice in defence.

anchor.surface_text: Even in his written representation dated November 12, 1949, the appellant did number allege that he was prejudiced in his defence.

facts.text: Court found appellant had reasonable opportunity to defend.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the appellant had reasonable opportunity to defend himself against the charges.

facts.text: High Court accepted respondent's first contention and declined opinion on second.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the first companytention, and declined to express any opinion on the second companytention.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds second contention of respondent sound, declines opinion on first.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the second companytention of the respondent is sound, ,and in this view of the matter, we decline to express any opinion on the first companytention.

facts.text: Order dated October 17, 1950 directed dismissal with effect from May 20, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The order dated October 17, 1950 directed that the appellant be dismissed from service with effect from the date of his suspension, that is to say, from May 20, 1949.

facts.text: Court holds order of dismissal valid and effective as from October 17, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The order of dismissal as from October 17, 1950 is valid and effective.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is dismissed.
The appellant number appeals to this Court by special leave.

Counsel for the appellant submitted that in view of the refusal of the appeals prayer for engaging a companynsel of his own choice and his prayer for adjournment of the hearing on June 13, 1949, the appellant had been denied a reasonable opportunity to defend himself against the charges.

Even in his written representation dated November 12, 1949, the appellant did number allege that he was prejudiced in his defence. We are satisfied that the appellant had reasonable opportunity to defend himself against the charges.

concepts.interpretation: No conflict of interests with co-accused counsel; tribunal permitted use of same counsel; enquiry lasted three days; no proof counsel unable to conduct defence properly; no allegation of prejudice raised contemporaneously.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: of the appeals prayer for engaging a companynsel of his own choice and his prayer for adjournment of the hearing on June 13, 1949, the appellant had

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant next companytended that the order of dismissal dated October 17, 1950 having been passed with re- trospective effect is illegal and inoperative. Counsel for the respondent submitted  1  the order of dismissal with retrospective effect as from the date of the suspension is valid in its entirety, and  2  in any event, the order is valid and effective as from October 17, 1950.

concepts.unlisted_description: Dismissal orders specifying both prospective dismissal and retrospective effect contain separable parts.

anchor.surface_text: The order dated October 17, 1950 directed that the appellant be dismissed from service with effect from the date of his suspension, that is to say, from May 20, 1949. In substance, this order directed that   1   the appellant be dismissed, and  2  the dismissal do operate retrospectively as from May 20, 1949. The two parts ,of this companyposite order are separable. The first part of the order ,operates as a dismissal of the appellant as from October 17, 1950. The invalidity of the second part of the order, assuming this part to be invalid, does number affect the first part of the order. The order of dismissal as from October 17, 1950 is valid and effective.

concepts.interpretation: An order of dismissal with retrospective effect is in substance a prospective dismissal with superadded retrospective direction; parts are severable; court can enforce valid prospective part even if retrospective invalid; cannot create new order but upholds severable portion.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: issal as from October 17, 1950 is valid and effective. The appellant has been lawfully dismissed, and he is number entitled to claim that he is still

concepts.unlisted_description: Dismissal orders specifying both prospective dismissal and retrospective effect contain separable parts.

anchor.surface_text: We may number numberice the cases relied on by companynsel for the appellant. In Hemanta Kumar v. S. N. Mukherjee 1 , the Calcutta High Court had occasion to companysider an order dated April 29, 1952 by which a civil servant had been placed under suspension with retrospective effect from January 16, 1951. While holding that the order of suspension for the period, January 16, 1951 up to April 28, 1952 was invalid and should be quashed, the Court held that the order of suspension was valid and effective as and from April 29, 1952 and this part of the order should be upheld.

concepts.interpretation: Distinguishes cases holding orders stand or fall in toto; prefers severability as in Hemanta Kumar where retrospective suspension severed, upholding prospective part.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ing that the dismissal from the period from July 15. 1951 up to April 17, 1952 was invalid, the High Court also held that the order of dismissal was e

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the appellant had reasonable opportunity to defend himself against the charges.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No conflict of interests with other civil servants; tribunal permitted engagement of same counsel; three-day enquiry provided adequate time; no evidence counsel unable to defend properly; no allegation of prejudice in contemporaneous written representation.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the second contention of the respondent is sound, and in this view of the matter, we decline to express any opinion on the first contention.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the second contention of the respondent is sound, ,and in this view of the matter, we decline to express any opinion on the first contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order's prospective dismissal component independent and severable from retrospective direction; accepts alternative argument rendering first contention unnecessary.

holdings.text: The two parts of this composite order are separable. The first part of the order operates as a dismissal of the appellant as from October 17, 1950. The invalidity of the second part of the order, assuming this part to be invalid, does not affect the first part of the order. The order of dismissal as from October 17, 1950 is valid and effective.

anchor.surface_text: The order dated October 17, 1950 directed that the appellant be dismissed from service with effect from the date of his suspension, that is to say, from May 20, 1949. In substance, this order directed that   1   the appellant be dismissed, and  2  the dismissal do operate retrospectively as from May 20, 1949. The two parts ,of this composite order are separable. The first part of the order ,operates as a dismissal of the appellant as from October 17, 1950. The invalidity of the second part of the order, assuming this part to be invalid, does number affect the first part of the order. The order of dismissal as from October 17, 1950 is valid and effective.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order in substance contains distinct directions for dismissal and retrospective operation; parts severable per textual analysis; follows Hemanta Kumar precedent upholding severed prospective part; distinguishes Abdul Hamid rejecting in toto approach.
